source: FDA Cardiovascular Device Terminology + ISO 11070 + Medical Device Nomenclature

balloon_compliance.definition: Change in balloon diameter per unit change in inflation pressure; classified as compliant (>0.02 mm/atm), semi-compliant (0.01-0.02 mm/atm), or non-compliant (<0.01 mm/atm)
balloon_compliance.regulatory_context: Must report compliance curve (diameter vs. pressure) in device master file; affects vessel sizing accuracy
balloon_compliance.test_method: ISO 25539-1 Annex C - inflate balloon in 37°C water bath; measure diameter at 2 atm increments using optical comparator
balloon_compliance.typical_values: Non-compliant: 0.005-0.01 mm/atm; Semi-compliant: 0.01-0.02 mm/atm; Compliant: 0.02-0.10 mm/atm
balloon_compliance.clinical_significance: Non-compliant balloons preferred for precise dilation; compliant for vessel apposition in tortuous anatomy

rated_burst_pressure.definition: Maximum pressure at which balloon can be inflated without rupture, as specified by manufacturer; typically 95% of burst pressure from testing
rated_burst_pressure.regulatory_context: FDA requires verification testing per ISO 25539-1; label must state RBP and nominal pressure
rated_burst_pressure.test_method: ISO 25539-1 Section 7.5.2 - inflate balloon to failure; RBP = mean burst pressure - 2SD
rated_burst_pressure.typical_values: Angioplasty balloons: 12-20 atm RBP; Non-compliant balloons: 18-35 atm RBP
rated_burst_pressure.clinical_significance: Operator must not exceed RBP to avoid balloon rupture and potential vessel injury

nominal_pressure.definition: Inflation pressure at which balloon achieves labeled diameter in free air at 37°C
nominal_pressure.regulatory_context: Labeled on device; typically 6-10 atm for angioplasty balloons
nominal_pressure.test_method: ISO 25539-1 - inflate balloon in 37°C water bath to specified pressure; measure diameter with optical comparator (±0.1 mm tolerance)
nominal_pressure.typical_values: Coronary balloons: 6-10 atm nominal; Peripheral balloons: 8-12 atm nominal
nominal_pressure.clinical_significance: Starting pressure for dilation; vessel sizing accuracy depends on achieving nominal pressure

trackability.definition: Ability of catheter to navigate tortuous vascular anatomy without prolapsing or failing to advance
trackability.regulatory_context: Assessed in benchtop testing (simulated anatomy models) and clinical evaluation
trackability.test_method: Push catheter through tortuous mock vessel (multiple 90° bends); measure push force and success rate
trackability.typical_values: Guidewire support force <1 N for successful tracking; failure = catheter prolapse or guidewire buckling
trackability.clinical_significance: Poor trackability increases procedure time and risk of vessel trauma from excessive force

crossability.definition: Ability of catheter to cross a tight stenosis or total occlusion without device damage or dislodgement
crossability.regulatory_context: Assessed in benchtop stenosis model and clinical studies (crossing success rate)
crossability.test_method: Push catheter through calibrated stenosis model (e.g., 0.5 mm lumen); measure crossing force and damage
crossability.typical_values: Crossing force <0.5 N for lesion access; profile ≤0.017" (0.43 mm) for severe stenosis
crossability.clinical_significance: Low-profile designs (thin balloon, low crossing profile) improve crossability in complex lesions

pushability.definition: Longitudinal stiffness of catheter shaft enabling forward force transmission from proximal to distal end
pushability.regulatory_context: Relates to catheter column strength; must balance with flexibility for tracking
pushability.test_method: Measure column strength - axial load at buckling when catheter pushed in straight tube
pushability.typical_values: Column strength 0.3-0.8 N for coronary catheters; higher for peripheral/support catheters
pushability.clinical_significance: Inadequate pushability causes catheter prolapse; excessive stiffness impairs trackability

kink_resistance.definition: Ability of catheter to withstand sharp bends without lumen collapse or permanent deformation
kink_resistance.regulatory_context: Test per device-specific protocol; ensure lumen patency after 90° bend
kink_resistance.test_method: Bend catheter 90° around mandrel of specified radius; verify lumen patency (fluid flow or wire passage)
kink_resistance.typical_values: Minimum bend radius 5-10 mm for coronary catheters without kinking
kink_resistance.clinical_significance: Kinked catheter obstructs guidewire, contrast, or drug delivery; may require device removal

guidewire_compatibility.definition: Range of guidewire diameters that catheter lumen accommodates for over-the-wire or rapid-exchange delivery
guidewire_compatibility.regulatory_context: Must specify in IFU; verify that catheter tracks over labeled guidewire sizes
guidewire_compatibility.test_method: Advance catheter over guidewires at lower and upper specification limits; assess tracking smoothness
guidewire_compatibility.typical_values: Coronary catheters: 0.014" (0.36 mm) guidewire; Peripheral: 0.018"-0.035" (0.46-0.89 mm)
guidewire_compatibility.clinical_significance: Incompatible guidewire causes excessive friction or catheter damage

radiopacity.definition: Visibility of catheter markers under fluoroscopy to enable positioning and deployment verification
radiopacity.regulatory_context: Radiopaque markers (platinum, gold, tantalum) required at balloon ends and catheter tip
radiopacity.test_method: Fluoroscopic imaging per ASTM F640; measure contrast ratio (marker to background)
radiopacity.typical_values: Marker bands 0.05-0.15 mm thick; platinum-iridium alloy (90/10) provides optimal radiopacity without artifact
radiopacity.clinical_significance: Poor marker visibility leads to imprecise positioning and suboptimal outcomes

tip_design.definition: Catheter distal tip geometry; atraumatic (rounded, soft) for safety; tapered for lesion entry; tip length typically 1-5 mm
tip_design.regulatory_context: Assess tip flexibility and profile in benchtop testing; clinical evaluation of vessel trauma
tip_design.test_method: Penetration force test - measure force to penetrate membrane (low force = atraumatic)
tip_design.typical_values: Penetration force <0.1 N for atraumatic tips; tip outer diameter ≤catheter shaft diameter
tip_design.clinical_significance: Atraumatic tip reduces perforation risk; tapered tip facilitates crossing tight lesions

rewrap_reliability.definition: Ability of balloon to deflate and rewrap compactly for withdrawal through deployed stent or lesion
rewrap_reliability.regulatory_context: Assess in benchtop and clinical studies; document rewrap profile in DMR
rewrap_reliability.test_method: Inflate balloon to RBP, deflate using vacuum syringe, measure rewrapped profile with laser micrometer
rewrap_reliability.clinical_significance: Poor rewrap causes difficult withdrawal, stent dislodgement, or vessel trauma

inflation_deflation_time.definition: Time for balloon to reach nominal pressure (inflation) or return to ambient pressure (deflation)
inflation_deflation_time.regulatory_context: Document in device master file; affects procedure duration
inflation_deflation_time.test_method: Connect balloon to indeflator; measure time from 0 to nominal pressure (inflation) and nominal to 0 (deflation)
inflation_deflation_time.typical_values: Inflation: 3-10 seconds; Deflation: 5-15 seconds (shorter with active vacuum)
inflation_deflation_time.clinical_significance: Rapid inflation/deflation reduces ischemia time during coronary dilation

particulate_generation.definition: Particles released from device surface or coating during simulated use (inflation, tracking, withdrawal)
particulate_generation.regulatory_context: Test per ISO 10993-12; critical for drug-coated balloons and stent delivery systems
particulate_generation.test_method: ISO 10993-12 - simulate use in closed fluid system; filter eluate; count particles >10 μm by light obscuration or microscopy
particulate_generation.typical_values: Acceptance: <100 particles >25 μm per device (ISO 10993-12 baseline); <10 particles >50 μm
particulate_generation.clinical_significance: Particulate embolization may cause distal vessel occlusion (no-reflow phenomenon)

drug_coating_integrity.definition: For drug-coated balloons: uniformity, adhesion, and retention of drug coating during handling and delivery
drug_coating_integrity.regulatory_context: FDA requires coating characterization and loss during simulated use; elution profile documentation
drug_coating_integrity.test_method: Measure coating thickness (SEM), drug content (HPLC), and loss after tracking through stenosis model
drug_coating_integrity.typical_values: Coating thickness 2-10 μm; drug retention ≥70% after tracking through tortuous model
drug_coating_integrity.clinical_significance: Coating loss during delivery reduces drug transfer to vessel wall and efficacy

tip_entry_profile.definition: Maximum outer diameter of catheter distal end (tip + folded balloon); critical for crossing tight lesions
tip_entry_profile.regulatory_context: Measure and report in labeling; affects crossability
tip_entry_profile.test_method: Measure with laser micrometer or optical comparator at narrowest point patient vessel encounters
tip_entry_profile.typical_values: Coronary balloon catheters: 0.016"-0.020" (0.41-0.51 mm); Peripheral: 0.030"-0.060" (0.76-1.52 mm)
tip_entry_profile.clinical_significance: Lower profile enables access to distal, tortuous, or calcified lesions

balloon_material.definition: Polymer used for balloon membrane; affects compliance, strength, and fatigue resistance
balloon_material.regulatory_context: Common materials: PET (polyethylene terephthalate), nylon (polyamide), Pebax (polyether block amide)
balloon_material.test_method: Material identification by FTIR; mechanical testing per ISO 25539-1
balloon_material.typical_values: PET: non-compliant, high strength; Nylon: semi-compliant, moderate strength; Pebax: compliant, lower strength
balloon_material.clinical_significance: Material selection balances compliance needs with burst resistance and rewrap capability

shaft_construction.definition: Multilayer catheter shaft with inner liner (PTFE, HDPE), reinforcement (stainless steel braid/coil), and outer jacket (Pebax, polyurethane)
shaft_construction.regulatory_context: Document materials and bond strength in DMR; ensure no layer separation
shaft_construction.test_method: Bond strength per ISO 10555-1; delamination resistance via peel test
shaft_construction.typical_values: Inner liner: PTFE (low friction); Reinforcement: 304V stainless steel braid (torque transmission); Outer jacket: Pebax (flex gradient)
shaft_construction.clinical_significance: Shaft integrity critical for pushability, torqueability, and kink resistance

hydrophilic_coating.definition: Lubricious surface coating (typically polyvinylpyrrolidone or polyacrylamide) to reduce friction in wet state
hydrophilic_coating.regulatory_context: Test coating durability, particulate, and biocompatibility per ISO 10993 series
hydrophilic_coating.test_method: Measure static and kinetic friction coefficient before and after simulated use
hydrophilic_coating.typical_values: Uncoated catheter: friction coefficient 0.3-0.5; Hydrophilic coated: 0.02-0.10 (wet)
hydrophilic_coating.clinical_significance: Reduces tracking force and vessel trauma; coating must withstand delivery without delamination

biocompatibility.definition: ISO 10993 series testing for blood-contacting devices with limited duration (<24 hours) or prolonged (24 hours to 30 days) contact
biocompatibility.regulatory_context: Typical tests: cytotoxicity (ISO 10993-5), sensitization (10993-10), irritation (10993-10), systemic toxicity (10993-11), hemocompatibility (10993-4), pyrogenicity (10993-11)
biocompatibility.test_method: Follow ISO 10993-1 risk-based approach; extract device in saline or polar solvent for in vitro tests
biocompatibility.typical_values: Cytotoxicity: no Zone 1 effect; Hemolysis: <5%; Sensitization/Irritation: no reaction
biocompatibility.clinical_significance: Ensures device materials do not cause adverse tissue or blood reactions

sterilization_validation.definition: Demonstration of sterility assurance level (SAL) 10^-6 via ethylene oxide (EO), gamma irradiation, or e-beam per ISO 11135/11137
sterilization_validation.regulatory_context: Provide sterilization validation report in 510(k); include dose mapping (radiation) or load pattern (EO)
sterilization_validation.test_method: ISO 11135 (EO): half-cycle, overkill, or bioburden-based approach. ISO 11137 (radiation): VDmax or dose substantiation
sterilization_validation.typical_values: EO: 600 mg·L^-1·h exposure; Gamma: 25 kGy dose; E-beam: 25-50 kGy dose
sterilization_validation.clinical_significance: Sterile device required for intravascular use; residual EO limits: <10 ppm EO, <250 ppm ECH, <250 ppm EG

shelf_life.definition: Duration device maintains sterility and performance from manufacture to expiration date
shelf_life.regulatory_context: Real-time aging (preferred) or accelerated aging per ASTM F1980; minimum 2-year claim typical
shelf_life.test_method: Accelerated aging at 55°C (2× aging factor per Arrhenius); test sterile barrier integrity (ASTM F1980), device performance
shelf_life.typical_values: Typical shelf life claims: 2-3 years for catheters; test at T0, T6mo, T12mo, T24mo (real-time) or equivalent accelerated
shelf_life.clinical_significance: Expired devices may have compromised sterility or degraded performance (e.g., balloon burst pressure decline)

usage_notes.french_size: Catheter outer diameter in French (1 Fr = 0.33 mm = 0.013"). Coronary catheters typically 5-7 Fr; peripheral 4-12 Fr
usage_notes.over_the_wire_vs_rapid_exchange: OTW = full-length guidewire lumen; RX = short distal guidewire lumen (~25 cm). RX allows single-operator technique
usage_notes.working_length: Usable catheter length from hub to distal tip; typically 135-150 cm for coronary, 40-260 cm for peripheral based on access site
usage_notes.pressure_units: Atmospheres (atm) = standard; 1 atm = 14.7 psi = 101.3 kPa. Inflation devices (indeflators) graduated in atm
usage_notes.contrast_media: Non-ionic low-osmolar contrast (iohexol, iopamidol) recommended; avoid air bubbles (embolism risk)
